title: Raffaele Ferlotti
text:
Raffaele Ferlotti (27 February 1819 – 11 November 1891) was an Italian <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="baritone">baritone</a> who had an active international career from the 1830s through the 1860s. He was a regular performer in Italy's leading opera houses, especially <a href="La%20Scala">La Scala</a>, and created roles in several world premieres. On the international stage he performed in operas in Austria, England, France, and Spain.
Life and career.
Born in <a href="Bologna">Bologna</a>, Ferlotti was the son of <a href="choreographer">choreographer</a> Nicola Ferlotti and <a href="ballerina">ballerina</a> Paola Scutelari. His older sister was the soprano Santina Ferlotti-Sangiorgi. The first known performance by Ferlotti was as concert soloist in Ravenna in 1835. Later that year he appeared at the Teatro Comunale in Faenza as Bartolomeo in <a href="Gaetano%20Donizetti">Gaetano Donizetti</a>'s "<a href="Il%20furioso%20all%27isola%20di%20San%20Domingo">Il furioso all'isola di San Domingo</a>". He was soon invited to make appearances at major <a href="opera%20house">opera house</a>s throughout Italy. In 1836 he appeared at the <a href="Teatro%20Comunale%20di%20Bologna">Teatro Comunale di Bologna</a> as Tartufo in <a href="Carlo%20Coccia">Carlo Coccia</a>'s "Clotilde". He returned to that house in 1842 to sing the title role in <a href="Federico%20Ricci">Federico Ricci</a>'s "Corrado d'Altamura". In 1838 he made his debut at the <a href="Teatro%20Regio%20di%20Parma">Teatro Regio di Parma</a> as Israele in Donizett's "<a href="Marino%20Faliero%20%28opera%29">Marino Faliero</a>". He returned to that theatre in 1841 to portray Enrico Ashton in Donizetti's "<a href="Lucia%20di%20Lammermoor">Lucia di Lammermoor</a>" with <a href="Teresa%20De%20Giuli-Borsi">Teresa De Giuli-Borsi</a> in the title role. He also appeared in Parma in 1842 as Contareno in <a href="Henri%20Cohen%20%28composer%29">Henri Cohen</a>'s "Antonio Foscarini", Don Alfonso d'Este in Donizetti's "<a href="Lucrezia%20Borgia%20%28opera%29">Lucrezia Borgia</a>", and Publio in <a href="Saverio%20Mercadante">Saverio Mercadante</a>'s "<a href="La%20vestale%20%28Mercadante%29">La vestale</a>".
In 1840 Ferlotti arrived at <a href="La%20Fenice">La Fenice</a> where he appeared as Assur in <a href="Gioachino%20Rossini">Gioachino Rossini</a>'s "<a href="Semiramide">Semiramide</a>", the Count of Vergy in Donizetti's "<a href="Gemma%20di%20Vergy">Gemma di Vergy</a>", Giorgio Talbot in "<a href="Maria%20Stuarda">Maria Stuarda</a>", and <a href="Guido%20della%20Torre">Guido della Torre</a> in <a href="Alessandro%20Nini">Alessandro Nini</a>'s "Ida della Torre". On 5 September 1840 he made his debut at <a href="La%20Scala">La Scala</a> as the Cavaliere di Belfiore in the world premiere of <a href="Giuseppe%20Verdi">Giuseppe Verdi</a>'s "<a href="Un%20giorno%20di%20regno">Un giorno di regno</a>". Although that opera was a failure, he sang two more roles at that house later that year to much greater success: Briano in <a href="Otto%20Nicolai">Otto Nicolai</a>'s "<a href="Il%20templario">Il templario</a>" and Ernesto in <a href="Vincenzo%20Bellini">Vincenzo Bellini</a>'s "<a href="Il%20pirata">Il pirata</a>". He returned to La Scala several more times during his career, notably performing in the world premieres of <a href="Temistocle%20Solera">Temistocle Solera</a>'s "Il contadino d'Agleiate" (1841), <a href="Achille%20Graffigna">Achille Graffigna</a>'s "Ildegondo e Rizzario" (1841), Ruggero in <a href="Giovanni%20Pacini">Giovanni Pacini</a>'s "L'ebrea" (1844), <a href="Luigi%20Petrali">Luigi Petrali</a>'s "Sofonisba" (1844), and in such roles as the Count of Vergy (1842) and Ernesto Malcolm in <a href="Giovanni%20Pacini">Giovanni Pacini</a>'s "<a href="Maria%2C%20regina%20d%27Inghilterra">Maria, regina d'Inghilterra</a>" (1843).
In 1845 Ferlotti appeared in operas by Verdis and Donizetti at the <a href="Teatro%20Real">Teatro Real</a> in Madrid. In 1848 he performed as a guest artist at the <a href="Teatro%20di%20San%20Carlo">Teatro di San Carlo</a> in Naples as Don Alfonso d'Este, Israele, and the title hero in Verdi's "<a href="Nabucco">Nabucco</a>". He sang Don Alfonso d'Este there again in 1849 and in 1850 was heard in Naples as Severo in Donizetti's "<a href="Poliuto">Poliuto</a>". In 1855 he portrayed the Miller in Verdi's "<a href="Luisa%20Miller">Luisa Miller</a>" at the <a href="Teatro%20Argentina">Teatro Argentina</a> in Rome. In 1858–1859 he was committed to the <a href="Liceu">Liceu</a> in Barcelona. He also performed as a guest artist at the <a href="Paris%20Opera">Paris Opera</a>, the <a href="Royal%20Opera%20House">Royal Opera House</a> in London, and the <a href="Vienna%20State%20Opera">Vienna State Opera</a>. After retiring from the stage in the early 1860s, he taught singing in Bologna at a school he founded with his sister around 1850. One of his students there was his niece, <a href="Giuseppina%20Vitali">Giuseppina Vitali</a>, who followed in his footsteps on stages throughout Europe as an opera singer. He died in Bologna in 1891 at the age of 72.
